attributes.description: 5.4% of California's fresh strawberry product and 16.0% of frozen product was exported to Mexico in 2011 (California Strawberry Commission 2012).
attributes.title: Mexican Consumers

attributes.description: 2.9% of California's fresh strawberries and 13.1% of frozen product was exported to Japan in 2011 (California Strawberry Commission 2012).
attributes.title: Japanese Consumers

attributes.description:
Canada is the highest consumer of fresh and frozen California strawberries, with 86.5% and 63.4% respectively, of the product crossing the 49th parallel in 2011 (California Strawberry Commission 2012).

Due to a much smaller growing season (approximately one month) the California strawberry industry is outcompeting Canada’s domestic market (Langford n.d.). Canadian farmers also attribute growing costs of land, fertilizer, labour and fuel as contributing factors to the decrease in Canadian operated strawberry farms (The Vancouver Sun 2006). The arrival of the strawberry in grocery stores in the month of June once signified the start of summer for many Canadians (Langford n.d). Now however, with year long availability, the strawberry is no longer viewed as a luxury item as nine to ten months of year Canadians can find these tasty berries in the produce aisles of their local grocery store (The Vancouver Sun 2006).
attributes.title: Canadian Consumers

attributes.description: Once strawberries are picked timing is crucial; the strawberries need to be cooled in order to prevent premature spoiling. This is done in processing plants primarily in Watsonville. After cooling the berry packaging containers are subjected to a Techtral treatment that essentially replaces oxygen in the container with carbon dioxide in order to further prevent spoiling during transport (Porter 2009). If bound for destinations throughout North America, approximately three and half hours after the strawberries have left the field they are loaded onto trucks to be delivered (Porter 2009).
attributes.title: Watsonville Distribution Centres

attributes.description:
Field workers are often immigrant or migrant workers who for the most part are of Mexican birth or descent (Wells 1996:56). Although a large portion of these workers are illegal immigrants, the exact number of undocumented workers, or indocumentados, is difficult to determine.

Strawberry pickers generally belong within one of two social categories: individual, young males not accompanied by spouse or family and families, including husband, wife, and children. (Wells 1996:156). Social networks are crucial for workers as it is through familial connections that they often gain employment. When harvest season is in its peak, growers rely on permanent workers’ family and social networks to find seasonal employees (Wells 1996:155). Workers’ ability to earn relatively high income in a short period of time and their responsibilities to support family members are factors that increase their commitment to work and decrease refusal of poor working conditions (Wells 1996:155).
attributes.title: Workers from Mexico

attributes.description: US Davis cultivars thrive in Mexico (FPS 2008).
attributes.title: Mexico

attributes.description: US Davis cultivars thrive in Spain (FSD 2008).
attributes.title: Spain
Salinas Valley
attributes.description:
The most southerly micro-region of the strawberry industry, the Salinas Valley, is characterized by large scale farms averaging over seventy acres (Wells 1996:103). Although the Salinas Valley is expansive, “strawberries are only grown in its ocean-tempered northern twenty miles” (Wells 1996:101). 

In the Salinas Valley, the high volume of farm acreage allows for job and wage competition from nearby vegetable farms. As a result, “strawberry workers are the most likely to openly challenge the terms of employment” (Wells 1996:196), in this area.

attributes.title: Pajaro Valley
attributes.description:
The Pajaro Valley is the northern most berry-growing micro-region with rich soils along the alluvial plain and river terraces. The enclosing hills of the valley provide shelter for these delicate berries (Wells 1996:98-99).

The level and stability of wages is highest in the Pajaro Valley due in part to the fact that most farms are owner-operated and enjoy the highest level of market stability (Wells 1996:196).

attributes.title: Monterey Hills
attributes.address: Monterey Hills, Los Angeles, CA, USA
attributes.description:
The North Monterey Hills micro-region is characterized by narrow valleys and steep granite hillsides. For the most part this area has mostly small scale farms due to the irregular topography of ancient sand dunes and thin topsoil overlaying the hilly terrain (Wells 1996:99-101).

The North Monterey Hills attracts more undocumented workers due to its geographical barriers and remoteness allowing for inconsistent and unfair wages of migrant workers (Wells 1996:205)

attributes.title: UC Davis Cultivars
attributes.address: University of California, Davis, 1 Shields Avenue, Davis, CA 95616, USA
attributes.description:
Foundation Plant Services is a top research department at UC Davis that conducts rigorous disease testing of various strawberry species in an attempt to provide growers with healthy plant stock. “Strawberry growers rely on UC Davis Foundation Plant Services to provide nurseries with virus-tested, correctly identified planting stock of the newest and best UC-patented strawberry cultivar” (FPS 2008). 

“More than 70 percent of the strawberries produced in California are from UC Davis cultivars” (FPS 2008). The UC Davis Strawberry Licensing Program provides nurseries and growers with a licensing agreement to produce their patented cultivars. 

US Davis cultivars thrive in many other parts of the world was well such as Spain, Mexico, Morocco, and Australia.
